author: Agency Staff
title: South African retail sales beat expectations | Economy
text:
Picture: THINKSTOCK Related articles Chinese steel output may collapse 20%, Baosteel chairman says Fiat Chrysler falls as Ferrari misses investors’ high expectations Discount retailers play expensive game of follow-my-leader SAP says could beat targets on cloud’s silver lining RETAIL sales grew above expectations in August, though the outlook for the sector’s quarterly performance remain muted.
Retail sales rose 3.9% year on year in August after expanding 3.3% in July, Statistics South Africa said on Wednesday.
Month on month, sales were up 1.5%, and rose by 3.7% in the three months to August compared with the year-earlier period, Stat SA said.
"Nevertheless, for the third quarter as a whole, growth in the retail sector is unlikely to be particularly buoyant, based on survey evidence," Kamilla Kaplan of Investec said.
"The third-quarter BER retail trade confidence survey indicated that confidence among retailers declined as sales volume growth proved weaker than anticipated.
"Moreover, retailers did not envisage an improvement in trading conditions in the fourth quarter."
She said consumer confidence was depressed and consumers faced growing pressure from rising living costs and indebtedness, as well as the prospect of further tax increases.
The main contributors to the 3.9% year-on-year increase were general dealers (contributing 2.1 percentage points), retailers in textiles, clothing, footwear and leather goods (contributing 0.9 percentage points) and all other retailers (contributing 0.7 of a percentage point), Stats SA said.
The highest annual growth rates were recorded for:
• all other retailers (6%);
• general dealers (5.2%); and
• retailers in textiles, clothing, footwear and leather goods (4.5%).
Seasonally adjusted retail trade sales increased 1% in the three months ended August compared with the previous three months.
The main contributors to the 3.7% year-on-year increase in the three months to August were:
• general dealers (4% and contributing 1.6 percentage points);
• retailers in textiles, clothing, footwear and leather goods (4.7% and contributing 0.9 percentage points); and
• all other retailers (5% and contributing 0.6 percentage points).
Reuters, with staff writer
